editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Your royalties were $73.02, which makes $36.51 apiece for you and Richard. You will find that I did not add a great deal to the money I sent you. By all means, keep it as a fund for your poor artists; or, better still, as a fund in case the submarine warfare makes the arrival of funds from America really difficult.

Fletcher has not said anything to me about going abroad. I don’t believe he will, unless the maritime situation clears up. Feeling is running rather high here just now; but I think you would be pleased with it if you were here. What I wrote Richard about America’s neutral attitude applies to the country at large – not to the section of it to which I, and others like me, belong.
Flint has bowed to our decision about "Evil", and has asked me to put in "War-time" instead. Of course, it comes very late, and the book is in the press; but I shall do my best to get it in.

This is not much of a letter, because – you will be glad to hear – my "Six French Poets" has already gone through its first edition, and I am very busy preparing a second one; and also getting ready my next volume of poems, to come out in the Autumn.

Yes, the lectures are going very well, and I think the people are paying more attention to imagism every day – at least, they no longer consider it the attitude of imbeciles and charlatans only. I think next Autumn I may extend my lecture tour a little further afield. Mr. Marsh says he can tell from the sale of my books where I have been, and I think that is equally true of the "Anthology", for I bring you all in the course of my lecture.
This is a very short letter because I am fearfully busy. I will write again in a few days, more at length.
I was asked out the other day to address a number of Harvard students on the subject, so you can see that the interest is spreading.
